results.title: Arthur and Corinne Cantrill interview
results.brief_description:
Arthur and Corinne Cantrill have been making films together since 1960. Initially focusing on documentaries about art they moved on to experimental film in 1969. From 1971 to 2000 they edited and published Cantrills Filmnotes, a journal on film and video art. Their film work and publishing are well-known internationally and have been represented in several film collections.

In this interview with Fiona Trigg, ACMI Exhibitions Assistant Curator, Arthur and Corinne talk about their early days of expanded cinema and their technical and creative processes.

results.title: Back to the brickworks
results.brief_description: In the 1800s, brickmaking was one of the largest manufacturing industries in Australia. Hoffman’s Brickworks in Brunswick, Victoria, was a leader of this industry, running for 133 years and fostering a strong union. Indeed Hoffman’s was the birthplace of the Brickmaker’s Union in Victoria. In this film, director Grant Hobson covers the final week of operation of this historic site, in December 1993. He interviews the union representatives and the close family of workers, some of whom he is able to reunite in May 2010 on the site. It is a nostalgic reflection on the heyday and demise of brickmaking in Victoria, as well as capturing the colourful personalities that illustrate the post-war migrant experience in relation to work and settling in Melbourne.

results.title: Turmoil [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
This challenging platform game takes place in the year 3000, amid environmental chaos. Your task is to deliver the final piece of a time machine that will allow scientists to travel to the past to introduce sustainable thinking practices.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.

results.title: Bins vs. Rubbish [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Ari Kritzerseferi, Auburn Primary School, Harry Dempsey, Jordan Trieu and Luc Thompson
results.brief_description:
A short excerpt from a computer game created for the 2010 ‘Screen It’ competition. This fun strategy game lets you dodge, catch and shoot rubbish. The message is to stop littering, as it can hurt animals and increase global warming.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.

results.title: [Celebrating the Site's Industrial Life]
results.brief_description: Originally established for the storing and handling of commercial explosives, the reserve is one of Altona’s few intact examples of its rich industrial history. This animation brings to life the story of explosives, the working life of the Truganina Explosives Reserve and its place in the history of Melbourne’s western region.

group.title: Unreserved : stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve

group_siblings.title: [The Vault]
group_siblings.creator_credit: Alan Young, Bill Nicholson Jr and Bronwen Gray

results.title: [Celebrating the Site's Flora and Fauna]
results.brief_description: Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona is an environmental wonderland, containing rare flora and fauna. Much of the original landscape has remained untouched for over 100 years. This takes us back to a time when it was formally landscaped, and representative of the early Edwardian planting of the late 1880s. Please enjoy a serene journey through the reserve, celebrating this unique ecosystem.
